text:
One way to getting around this I find is to not stress too much about having to re-write parts of your code.

Step 1: Write your code to the best of your ability.
Step 2: Benchmark, does it need optimizing?
Step 3: Optimize if optimization is needed.

More often than not, getting a working program up and running is more valuable than being meticulous with performance gains.

text: I'm in camp, write it fast and sloppy first. Think very minimally. Then if it becomes useful, and I find time later, optimize the slowest parts until its good enough. It's fun to optimize code but its also got a pretty high cost attributed too it. More often then not the need changes before optimization is even on the table.

text: Yeah, I don't agree with the "think minimally" part. I think it's worth some level of thinking up front to avoid having to rewrite it down the line. The thinking does not have to cost you that much.

text:
By minimally what I mean is - make obvious performance decisions upfront, but don't go down the rabbit hole.  IE: you really don't need to be writing things like @simd, or even benchmarking, etc in the first pass.

IMO - Its the industry mentality really. For the type of work I do you rarely know if your solution, performance at an optimum or not, will be relevent 2 weeks from its conception. So it's best to make something work as the problem statement evolves.
